para: Many Unix and Linux distributions use init scripts to start daemons in the same way that Unix System VSystem V did. This chapter will explain in detail how that works.

Init starts daemons by using scripts, where each script starts one daemon, and where each script waits for the previous script to finish. This serial process of starting daemons is slow, and although slow booting is not a problem on servers where uptime is measured in years, the recent uptake of Linux on the desktop results in user complaints.

To improve Linux startup speed, CanonicalCanonical has developed upstartupstart, which was first used in Ubuntu. Solaris also used init up to Solaris 9, for Solaris 10 SunSun developed Service Management FacilitySMF. Both systems start daemons in parallel and can replace the SysV init scripts. There is also an ongoing effort to create initnginitng (init next generation).

In 2014 the systemd initiative has taken a lead when after Fedora, RHEL7 and CentOS7 also Debian has chosen this to be the prefered replacement for init. The end of this module contains an introduction to systemd.
